text: [Music]
good afternoon from West London where
the Queen and Prince William have been
visiting people affected by the terrible
fire that that has engulfed Grenville
power three days ago the Queen and and
her grandson spent time speaking to
people who've been evacuated from the
surrounding area speaking to members of
the emergency services and to local
volunteers who of course have been being
praised by so many for all the time and
effort they put in to helping people who
survived just to bring you up to date
with what we know so far the police have
said that 17 people have now been
confirmed dead and the BBC understands
that as many as 76 are still missing we
believe that those 17 are included in
that number although that's not yet
confirmed there are 24 people who are
still in hospital and 12 people we know
are in a critical condition let me bring
in my colleague Peter hunt our royal
correspondent and we're watching Peter
aren't we the Queen making one of these
visits that she is bound to make on
occasions of national tragedy such as
this and I think what's very striking
about these images is that this is a
queen who keeps out of party politics
who tries to be a political but paying a
visit that will be judged in a very
political sense in the coming moments
hours and days because this is the Queen
giving a masterclass in how you respond
to a moment of national tragedy and it
is already on social media being
compared very unfavorably with Teresa
Mays failure thus far to meet any of the
victims of this tragedy and it reminds
me of how much the British royal family
has learnt and if you cast your minds
back to 1997 in the aftermath of the
death of Diana Princess of Wales
obviously the mother of Prince William
he was there with the Queen tabloids
after a few days have headline saying
show us you care when the Queen and the
royal family were criticized was staying
in Scotland and
coming to meet people in London that was
a very painful lesson for the royal
family 20 years ago 20 years on here you
see the Queen in this role that were
officials like to call it head of the
nation as a focal point often the focal
point at moments of celebration and
pleasure for the nation this obviously a
moment of sorrow and so she's come here
today with Prince William that in itself
is also a very significant moment a
reminder of how this is an institution
in transition and how the Queen is
relying more and more on its younger
members coming to say thank you to the
firefighters thank you to the volunteers
and meeting some of those who are
directly suffered as a result of this
fire
